titleStmt.title: Of a Young Lady at Oxford, 1646
Poem 43

encodingDesc.p: Transcriptions are encoded in TEI(P5)-conformant XML.

correction.p: Apparent errors are preserved and editorial corrections provided using SIC and CORR tags, but only where the editor conjectures that the original scribe or compositor would have recognized the instance as an error. For example, what according to modern usage is incorrect subject/verb agreement might have been deemed acceptable to a seventeenth-century scribe or compositor. All such instances are treated instead using the ORIG and REG tags. (See below.)

Corrections and annotations made within the scope of the original document either by its original authors, owners, and/or transcribers are noted using ADD tags. These annotations and may be further explained within NOTE tags, as added by the editors of this digital edition, for display within the apparatus.

normalization.p: Original spellings, abbreviations, and orthography are preserved. Where in the manuscripts a character’s status as majuscule or minuscule is ambiguous, the editor has silently chosen one or the other based on context and judgment (i.e., does not register such ambiguity in either the markup or the notes).

quotation.p: Original quotation marks, if any, are preserved.

glyph.glyphName: Handwritten 'ff' ligature, used in handwriting to represent modern F

listWit.witness: Transcription of manuscript: By Leah Knight and Wendy Wall.
Elemental edition: By Leah Knight and Wendy Wall.

app.rdg: PG#Of A young Lady atOxford 1646straight line under second half of “Oxford” and all of “1646”; end of previous poem occupies top of page

Of a Young Lady at
Oxford, 1646Oxford was a royalist stronghold in the first English civil war, which ended in 1646 with royalist surrender to parliamentary opponents.

Of a Young Lady at
Oxford, 1646Oxford was a Royalist stronghold and home to King Charles’s court during the First Civil War (1642-46). Oxford was besieged by Parliamentarian forces for three months in Spring 1646, and the Royalist garrison surrendered to General Thomas Fairfax on 24 June 1646. The reference to the death of Sir George Lucas and Sir Charles Lisle later in the poem indicates that the poem must have been completed in 1648 or later; however, the date in the title suggests that the story in the first half of the poem may be associated with the siege of Oxford.

rdg.note: In these transcriptions we preserve as many details of the original material, textual, and graphic properties of Hester Pulter’s manuscript verse as we have found practical. Whenever possible, for instance, original spelling, punctuation, capitalization, lineation, insertions, deletions, alterations, spacing between words and lines, and indentation are all maintained; abbreviations and brevigraphs are not expanded; and superscript and subscript representations are retained. See full conventions for the transcriptions here.

The aim of the elemental edition is to make the poems accessible to the largest variety of readers, which involves modernizing spelling and punctuation as well as adding basic glosses. Spelling and punctuation reflect current standard American usage; punctuation highlights syntax which might otherwise be obscure. Outmoded but still familiar word forms (“thou,” “‘tis,” “hold’st”) are not modernized, and we do not modernize grammar when the sense remains legible. After a brief headnote aimed at offering a “way in” to the poem’s unique qualities and connections with other verse by Pulter or her contemporaries, the edition features a minimum of notes and interpretative framing to allow more immediate engagement with the poem. Glosses clarify synonyms or showcase various possible meanings in Pulter’s time. Other notes identify named people and places or clarify obscure material. We rely (without citation) primarily on the Oxford English Dictionary (OED), the Oxford Reference database, and the King James Version (KJV) of the Bible. When we rely on Alice Eardley’s edition of Pulter’s work, we cite her text generally (“Eardley”); other sources are cited in full. The result is an edition we consider a springboard for further work on Pulter’s poetry. See full conventions for this edition here.
I have modernized spelling and punctuation in this poem with the aim of enhancing clarity and readability. The notes gloss unfamiliar words and provide cultural and literary contexts.

What was a young lady doing at Oxford in 1646? Shooting herself, according to Pulter, who reports what sounds like a cross between melodrama and a news bulletin of yet another example of the never-ending collateral damage of war. The speaker’s point, however, is not to regret this instance of self-murder, but to ennoble it through analogy with various other female suicides, before criticizing her own soul for lingering on earth despite allegedly loving Christ and seeking union with him in heaven. As part of a pep-talk to speed her own death, the speaker takes various rhetorical tacks. She recounts her inspired vision of the crucifixion, for instance, and compares Christ’s extraordinary heroism favorably with exemplary male friends who died for one another (since Christ outdid them by dying, not for his friends, but the “foes” of depraved humanity). All this is canvassed as part of the speaker’s somewhat haranguing campaign for her soul to leave her body without delay: a goal the young lady accomplished with the pull of a trigger, but which the Christian speaker, despite her evident admiration of this act and yearning for death, cannot achieve in the same manner while remaining loyal to her self-sacrificing (if not quite suicidal) “Redeemer.”

In “Of a Young Lady at Oxford, 1646,” Pulter develops complex relationships between political, erotic, and religious registers. The poem’s title refers to the anecdote that takes up about the first third of the poem, which describes the deaths of an unnamed pair of lovers during the Siege of Oxford in 1646. When the Lady learns that her lover, a Royalist soldier, has died in battle, she takes her own life in imitation of famous female suicides, Lucrece and Thisbe. This exemplum of erotic devotion, which Pulter describes as “earthy love,” prompts the speaker’s reflection upon the state of her soul. In an extended apostrophe to her soul, the speaker questions how her soul can desire to stay on earth when Christ, the soul’s proper companion, has already left it. Pulter mirrors the anecdote in the first part of the poem with the examples of five pairs—brothers, friends, lovers, and soldiers—who are famous for their devotion and willingness to die for one another. These exempla raise questions about whether different forms of human devotion are models for (or imitations of) the soul’s desire for union with Christ. The middle of the poem, however, includes several Biblical allusions that frame and reframe the classical allusions that begin and end the poem. While the unnamed Lady and the famous male heroes sacrifice themselves for friends or lovers, Christ dies for humans who are enemies (“cursed foes”) by dint of their sins (Romans 5: 7-8), a sacrifice that informs the speaker’s final, urgent questioning of her own soul.

app.rdg: A Noble pair in Love without Compare
A noble pair, in love without compare,
A noble pair in love without compare,
Heroick Spirits both Lovly and fair
Heroic spirits both, lovely and fair,
Heroic spirits both lovely and fair,
Whoſe Hearts were Counterchanged then then^noe wonderstruck-through with multiple horizontal lines; “noe wonder” directly above “then”
Whose hearts were counterchangedexchanged—then no wonder
Whose hearts were counterchanged; then no wonder,
They could not poſſible Subsist aſunder
They could not possibly subsist asunder.
They could not possibly subsist asunder.
Hee in this Grand Rebellion Late was kild
He, in this grand rebellionEnglish civil war late was killed
He in this grand rebellion late was killed.
&ff;or his good King his Loyall Blood was ſpild
For his good king; his loyal blood was spilled,
For his good king his loyal blood was spilled,
Which from the pregnant earth“h” in H2 Sprung up in fame
Which from the pregnant earth sprung up in fame,
Which from the pregnant earth sprung up in fame
Honouring him with a never dying Name
Honoring him with a never-dying name.
Honoring him with a never dying name.
This Gallant Las, thus having lost her Love
This gallant lass, thus having lost her love,
This gallant lass thus having lost her love,
Disdaind to imitate the Turtle Dove
Disdained to imitate the turtledovea bird noted for affection to its mate,
Disdained to imitate the turtledovebirds renowned for their monogamy and devotion. The turtledove is the subject of “The Poor Turtledove” (Emblem 20).,
Who mourning Sits upon a withred Spray
Who mourning sits upon a withered spraytwig or shoot:
Who mourning sits upon a withered spray.
Her Noble Heart Refuſd to Live one Day
Her noble heart refused to live one day
Her noble heart refused to live one day
Without her Love, earth noe contentment yields
Without her love. Earth no contentment yields.
Without her love. Earth no contentment yields.
Shee vowes to follow him to the Elizian &ff;ields
She vows to follow him to the Elysian fieldsIn Greek myth, this was the paradisal place where heroes went after death.,
She vows to follow him to the Elysian fieldsin Greek mythology, a blessed land where heroes live happily after their deaths.;
Then takes a Pistol in her Snowey Hand
Then takes a pistol in her snowy hand.
Then takes a pistol in her snowy hand,
Like a Roman Lucrece Soe did Shee Stand
Like a Roman LucreceLucrece was a married Roman woman who, after being brutally raped, chose to commit suicide rather than live in perceived dishonor., so did she stand,
Like a Roman Lucrece so did she stand
Who did prefer her Honour ’fore her Life
Who did prefer her honor ’forebefore her life,
Who did prefer her honor ’fore her life
And in her trembling Boſom thrust her Knife
And in her trembling bosom thrust her knife;
And in her trembling bosom thrust her knife;
Or like that Babylonish“y” appears corrected from earlier “i” Virgin Sweet
Or like that Babylonish virginThisbe, in love with Pyramus, kills herself when she thinks him dead. sweet
Or like that Babylonish virgin sweet
Who Saw her Love lie bleeding at her feet
Who saw her love lie bleeding at her feet—
Who saw her love lie bleeding at her feet
Shee with his Sword, her Spotles Breast did pierce
She, with his sword, her spotless breast did pierce,
She with his sword, her spotless breast did pierce
Which makes her live Still in \im \in H2 Mortal verſ
Which makes her live still in immortal verse—

Which makes her live still in immortal versethe young lady of Oxford is compared to two famous women whose suicides are also memorialized in poetry: Lucrece, who killed herself after she was raped by Tarquin in 510 BCE, and Thisbe (“Babylonish virgin sweet”) who commits suicide after she discovers the death (also a suicide) of her lover Pyramus. The stories of both of these women have repeatedly been the subject of poetry. Ovid writes of Lucrece in book II of Fasti, and Shakespeare adopts the story in The Rape of Lucrece (1594). The earliest version of the Pyramus and Thisbe story is found in Ovid’s Metamorphoses (book 4). Shakespeare uses this story for the plot of the play-within-a-play in A Midsummer’s Night Dream and also adapts it in Romeo and Juliet. Pulter updates these tales of heroic female suicide by including a modern weapon (the pistol).;
Soe this Heroick Maid display’d her Breast
So this heroic maid displayed her breast
So this heroic maid displayed her breast,
On which the God of Love was proud to Rest
On which the god of loveCupid was proud to rest;
On which the god of love was proud to rest,
The Sulpherus mouth plac’d at her generous Heart
The sulfurous mouthi.e., of the gun placed at her generous heart,
The sulfurous mouth placed at her generous heart,
Her Noble Mind triumphs or’e Death and Smart
Her noble mind triumphs o’er death and smartpain; grief.

Her noble mind triumphs o’er death and smartPulter interprets the Lady’s suicide as heroic, which corresponds to Stoic philosophy but is in conflict with Christian ethics. I have not been able to identify a specific historical analogue for the anecdote of a young lady’s suicide in Oxford during the Civil Wars, though the mixture specific historical details with classical precedent suggests that more research is warranted. If this story is fictional, Pulter has invented her own “fable” to place beside the classical exempla cited in the poem. If the story is historical, it is notable that Pulter does not condemn the Lady’s suicide, but interprets it as evidence of her nobility of spirit..
To Heaven Shee Rowls her Sparkling dieing Eyes
To Heaven she rolls her sparkling, dying eyes;
To Heaven she rolls her sparkling dying eyes;
&ff;rom her undaunted Breast her Spirit &ff;lyes
From her undaunted breast her spirit flies.
From her undaunted breast her spirit flies,
Even Soe a Spotles Lylley &ff;als and Dies
Even so a spotless lily falls and dies.
Even so a spotless lily falls and dies.
As this declares a m^agnanimous Spirit
As this declares a magnanimousnoble; courageous spirit,
As this declares a magnanimous spirit,
Soe Shee the Glory of it doth inherit
So she the glory of it doth inherit.
So she the glory of it doth inherit.
This Shee did doe to follow Earthey Love
This she did do to follow earthy love,

This she did do to follow earthy“consisting of earth, or of material resembling earth. Also used fig. of the human body, esp. a dead body” (OED "earthy" n. 1.c.). Pulter’s use of “earthy” rather than the more common “earthly” may reflect the interest in the elements displayed elsewhere in her poetry. See O, My Afflicted Solitary Soul and The Invocation of the Elements. love,
And thou my Soule whoſe Joys and Hope’s aboue
And thou, my soul, whose joys and hopes above
And thou, my soul, whose joys and hopes above
Are placed Still Hanckrest hovering here below
Are placed, still hank’restlingers, hovering here below:
Are placed, still hankerest, hovering here below.
Oh when wilt thou to thy Redeemer goe
O, when wilt thou to thy Redeemer go?
Oh, when wilt thou to thy redeemer go?
Thou keep’st a &ff;luttring here bout thiſ baſe earth
Thou keep’st afluttering here ’bout this base earth.
Thou keep’st afluttering here ’bout this base earth;
My Soul I doubt thou dos’t forget thy Birth
My soul, I doubtfear; suspect thou dost forget thy birth:
My soul, I doubt thou dost forget thy birth.
Thou art a Ray of that inviſiblethird “i” appears written over “u” Light
Thou art a ray of that invisible light:
Thou art a ray of that invisible light,
Thy wings noe impeing need, then take thy &ff;leight
Thy wings no impingengrafting feathers in a bird’s wing to remedy losses or deficiencies, and so restore or improve the powers of flight need; then take thy flight!

Thy wings no imping“to engraft feathers in the wing of a bird, so as to make good losses or deficiencies” (OED "imp," v. 4.). Compare to George Herbert’s “Easter Wings,” in which the speaker desires to “imp” his wing on Christ: “For, if I imp my wing on thine, / Affliction shall advance the flight in me.” need, then take thy flight.
Leav then this Low“w” written over other letter and Gloomey earthly Spheir
Leave then this low and gloomy earthly sphere;
Leave then this low and gloomy earthly sphere.
What dost thou mean, what dost thou hope, or fear
What dost thou mean—what dost thou hope, or fear?
What dost thou mean? What dost thou hope, or fear?
Tell mee is thy eternall buſines here
Tell me, is thy eternal business here?
Tell me, is thy eternal business here?
Hee whom thou lovest is gone, to Heaven hee’s &ff;led
He whom thou lovest is gone: to Heaven He’s fled.
He whom thou lovest is gone; to Heaven he’s fled.
Why dost thou Seek the Living amongst“st” crowded between surrounding words the Dead
Why dost thou seek the living amongst the dead?

rdg.seg: Why dost thou seek the living amongst the dead?Pulter alludes to Luke 24:5: “And as they were afraid, and bowed down their faces to the earth, they said unto them, Why seek ye the living among the dead?” (AV)

app.rdg: My active &ff;aith took wing and Late did fly
My active faith took wing and late did fly
My active faith took wing and late did fly
Upto the top of Canaans Calvary
Up to the top of Canaan’s CalvaryCalvary was where Christ was crucified; Canaan is the biblical promised land.;
Up to the top of Canaan’s Calvarythe location of Christ’s crucifixion..
There did I See with &ff;aiths Resplendent Eye
There did I see, with faith’s resplendentshining, brilliant eye,

There did I see with faith’s resplendent eyePulter describes her faith as an “active” aid to vision. The “resplendent” (shining) eye of faith allows her to “see” the crucifixion of Christ. Compare to This Was Written in 1648, When I Lay In, With my Son John in which the speaker’s “thoughts” allow a vision of the planets.
The &ff;ountain of all Love my Saviour Die
The fountain of all love, my Saviour, die.
The fountain of all love, my savior, die.
There did Longuives Peirce that guiltles brest

There did LonguivesLongeus, Longius, or Longinus is the traditional name for the Roman soldier at the Crucifixion who pierced Christ’s side with his spear to ensure that Christ was dead. pierce that guiltless breast

There did Longinusthe name traditionally given to the Roman soldier who pierced Jesus with his lance. See John 19:34: “But one of the soldiers with a spear pierced his side, and forthwith came there out of blood and water” (AV). pierce that guiltless brest
In which the &ff;aithfull Shall in Glory Rest
In which the faithful shall in glory rest.
In which the faithful shall in glory rest.
Ay mee there did his dieing Quickni^ng Blood
Ay me, there did His dying, quickeninglife-giving blood
Ay me! There did his dying quickening“to come or bring to life” (OED, "quicken," v. 1.); “dying quickening blood” is a paradox, suggesting that Christ’s blood renews life through death. blood
&ff;low from his Side for our eternal good
Flow from His side for our eternal good;
Flow from his side for our eternal good.
To Heaven his Righteous Soul did take his &ff;lieght
To Heaven His righteous soul did take His flight,
To Heaven his righteous soul did take his flight,
Leaving the Univerſ Lapt up in Night
Leaving the universe lapped up in night.

Leaving the universe lapped up in nightupon the death of his body, Christ’s soul returns to Heaven, leaving all of the created universe in darkness (“lapped up in night”). Compare Of Night and Morning..
O admirable, unparraleld affection
O admirable, unparalleled affection,
O admirable, unparalleled affection;
Thus by \ his fallwritten over illegible erased word(s) his &ff;all \in H2 recovering o:r defection
Thus, by His fall, recovering our defectionimperfection, shortcoming; abandonment of one’s religion, moral duty, cause or country!
Thus by his fall recovering our defection.
I am amazed at his infinite Love
I am amazed at His infinite love;
I am amazed at his infinite love;
&ff;or ^us hee left his Glorious Throne aboue
For us he left his glorious throne above.
For us he left his glorious throne above.
Though for a good Man one would Deign to die
Though for a good man one would deigncondescend; graciously accept to die,
Though for a good man one would deign to die,
Yet who would doe Soe for his enemie
Yet who would do so for his enemy?

Yet who would do so for his enemyPulter paraphrases Romans 5:7-8: “For scarcely for a righteous man will one die: yet peradventure for a good man some would even dare to die. But God commendeth his love toward us, in that, while we were yet sinners, Christ died for us.” (AV). This allusion frames the exempla that follow because each includes sacrifice on behalf of a friend or “good man” rather than an enemy, while Christ dies for humans who are his “cursed foes.”?
Damon, and Pithias, would Die for one another
Damon and PythiasIn classical legend, these faithful friends each strove to save the other from a sentence of death. would die for one another;
Damon and Pythias would die for one another,
Pollux divided Splendour with his Brother
PolluxZeus changed Pollux and his twin brother, Castor, into the constellation Gemini after Castor died and Pollux refused to part from him. divided splendor with his brother;
Pollux divided splendor with his brother,
Patrocles, and Achillis, loues excell

Patroclus and AchillesIn classical myth, these were Greek soldiers in the Trojan war. When Patroclus is killed by Hector, Achilles (who has until then refused to fight) avenges his best friend’s death by returning to battle and killing Hector.’s loves excel;
Patroclus’ and Achilles’ loves excel,
Theſeus reveng’d Perithous death in Hell
Theseus revenged Pirithous’s death in HellTheseus and Pirithous were close comrades who went to Hades; Theseus survived, but Pirithous did not.;
Theseus revenged Pirithous’ death in Hell,
When lovly Liſle"sle" written over earlier letters Saw Lucas Bleeding Lie

When lovely Lisle saw LucasGeorge Lisle and Charles Lucas were Royalist commanders in the siege of Colchester during the English civil war, who were executed by a firing squad without trial after their defeat and capture at Colchester in 1648. See Pulter’s On Those Two Unparalleled Friends, Sir George Lisle and Sir Charles Lucas. bleeding lie,
When lovely Lisle saw Lucas bleeding lie,
Hee on his trembling Booſome Strait did die
He on his trembling bosom straight did die.
He on his trembling bosom straight did die.
Thus doe theſe Storyes and theſe &ff;ables teach
Thus do these storiesi.e., histories and these fables teach

Thus do these stories and these fables teachPulter identifies five famous pairs to serve as partial analogues for Christ’s love and sacrifice for humans: 1) Damon offered himself as surety for his friend Pythias; 2) The immortal Pollux offered to share his immortality with his mortal twin Castor; 3) Patroclus is killed by Hector, and Achilles returns to battle to avenge the death of his lover; 4) Theseus and his friend Pirithous attempt travel to the underworld, where they intend to capture Persephone so Pirithous can marry her; when they fail, Pirithous is stranded in the underworld, and Theseus tries, and fails, to rescue him; 5) Lucas and Lisle are well known Royalist soldiers who were captured and executed by Parliamentarian forces at Colchester in 1648. While there is quite a bit of variation in the “love” demonstrated by each of these stories, the final pair is distinct because they are Pulter’s contemporaries. Lucas and Lisle were considered Royalist martyrs and were commemorated in numerous panegyrics and poems. See also Pulter’s On Those Two Unparalleled Friends, Sir George Lisle and Sir Charles Lucas, Who Were Shot to Death at Colchester.,
And Shew to us how fare our Love may Reach
And show to us how far our love may reach;
And show to us how far our love may reach.
But^hee (my Soul) his precious Blood did loſe
But He (my soul) His precious blood did lose
But he (my soul) his precious blood did lose
&ff;or us (Ay mee) for us his Curſſed &ff;oeſe“e” imperfectly erased
For us (ay me), for us: His curséd foes.
For us (ay me) for us his cursed foes.
Conſidering this my Soul how canst thou Stay
Considering this, my soul, how canst thou stay?
Considering this, my soul, how canst thou stay
Now hee is Gon, dost thou not know the way?
Now He is gone, dost thou not know the waySee John 14:6: "Jesus saith unto him, I am the way, the truth, and the life: no man cometh unto the Father, but by me."—
Now he is gone? Dost thou not know the way?
When little Infants new Created Souls
When little infants’ new-created souls
When little infants’ new created souls
Doe eaſily &ff;ly aboueimperfectly erased ascender suggests final “t” corrected to “e” or Star, or Poles,
Do easily fly above oreither star or poles,
Do easily fly above or star, or poles,
And &ff;rom their tender Mothers Ubrious Brest
And from their tender mother’s uberousfull; nourishing breast

And from their tender mother’s uberous“supplying milk or nourishment in abundance” (OED, “uberous,” adj. 1.a.). Though “tender” mothers nourish their infants with milk from their own breasts, children often die, but unlike the speaker’s own soul, they know the way to heaven. Their souls escape the earth and travel to a “star” or the “poles,” and they “fly to their eternal rest.” breast
Doe often &ff;ly to their eternall Rest
Do often fly to their eternal rest?
Do often fly to their eternal rest;
And thou my Soul witherd and Worn w: th Grief
And thou, my soul, withered and worn with grief:
And thou, my soul, withered and worn with grief,
Think’st in this Dunghill earth to find Relief
Think’st in this dunghillfilthy, excrement-like earth to find relief?
Think’st in this dunghill earth to find relief?
Believe it Terren hopes are all But vain
Believe it: terreneearthly hopes are all but vain,
Believe it: terrene“belonging to the earth or to this world; earthly, worldly, secular, temporal, material, human” (OED, "terrene," adj. 1.a.) hopes are all but vain;
&ff;or thou must cast thy Haccle once again

For thou must castcast off thy hacklecovering, as skin, or outer garment; the speaker proposes the skin or other earthly forms must be cast off “again” by way of returning to an original condition. once again

For thou must cast thy hackle“a cloak, a mantle, an outer garment”; or, “A covering or skin of any kind, esp. a snake’s skin” (OED, "hackle," n. 1. and 2.). Here “hackle” refers to the speaker’s body, which serves as a covering or “skin” for the soul. once again
Before thou canst poſſes thoſe endles Joyes
Before thou canst possess those endless joys,
Before thou canst possess those endless joys,
Cōpar’d with which all worldly Pomps are Toyes.
Compared with which all worldly pomps are toystrivial things.
Compared with which all worldly pomps are toys.
